awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   Spatial Dynamics, Early Warnings and Harmful Algal Blooms
awd_abstract_narration:
Small changes in the environment can have large effects on ecosystems when these changes approach a critical tipping point. For example, harmful algal blooms in lakes can appear suddenly in response to subtle changes in environmental conditions. Knowing when and where they are likely to happen in time to prevent them or to reduce their impact can be quite challenging. Some scientists have suggested that there may be early warnings of algal blooms detectable by frequent measurements of water quality. Recent advances in technology now make it possible to measure water quality in real time using sensors.  These high frequency data provide a way to develop early warnings of imminent blooms of harmful algae. An effective early warning system will help scientists understand what causes harmful algal blooms and develop strategies to prevent them. This research will study how to use spatial patterns, in addition to changes over time, to more effectively detect early warnings in lakes where harmful algal blooms are expected to occur. The goal is to create a new approach to predicting when and where large changes to ecosystems will occur. The results will be useful for management as harmful algal blooms are a serious water quality and public health problem. Early warnings before blooms begin could help managers protect beaches, water quality, and other important public resources. This project will also involve outreach to journalists to help educate the public about efforts to prevent harmful algal blooms.

Empirical evaluation of spatial pattern in ecosystems requires a means of repeatedly generating spatially rich data. The Fast Limnology Automated Measurement (FLAMe) platform rapidly determines the spatial distribution of a suite of variables including phytoplankton pigments that are diagnostic of algal blooms. The project will generate pigment maps and a variety of spatial statistics using the FLAMe platform. Spatial patterns will be studied for lakes across a natural nutrient loading gradient and for a set of eutrophic lakes. Dynamic spatial models of lake phytoplankton will be developed to evaluate existing indicators and possibly develop new ones. Lakes near thresholds for algal blooms are hypothesized to have higher spatial variance, autocorrelation, and skewness than either more oligotrophic (low nutrient inputs) or more eutrophic lakes (high nutrient inputs). Spatial early warnings will be tested in a whole lake manipulation that compares a nutrient enriched lake to an unenriched reference lake. The enriched lake is hypothesized to increase in spatial variance, autocorrelation, and skewness prior to the development of a bloom. The research will provide new knowledge of spatial patterns in lakes as nutrient status changes, as well as new insights about spatial variability and change indicators. The study will systematically explore spatial indicators for blooms and generate hypotheses testable in other types of ecosystems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Rapid shifts can result from relatively small changes in environmental factors when an ecosystem is near a threshold. In aquatic ecosystems, harmful algal blooms result from rapid shifts that favor explosive growth. These blooms can create poor water conditions, surface scums, and in some cases, production of algal toxins. Frequent measurements of common water quality variables such as dissolved oxygen and phytoplankton pigments provide early warnings of algal blooms. Prior research efforts have demonstrated that one such early warning indicator is a sudden increase in the variability of algal pigments measured at a high temporal frequency. In this study, we asked if similar changes occur for spatial patterns of algal pigments; that is, do differences from one location to another become amplified in advance of an algal bloom? We also hypothesized that that spatial variability in lakes would increase along a gradient from low productivity (oligotrophic) lakes to medium (mesotrophic) lakes and then decline in high (eutrophic) lakes. Early warning indicators based on high frequency temporal data and daily high-density spatial data from lakes near and far from thresholds for harmful algal blooms were compared to address these questions. Spatial heterogeneity of a large lake that undergoes frequent algal blooms was also analyzed focusing on responses to large precipitation events that flush nutrients into the lake contributing to blooms. Finally, spatial patterns were compared across a range of lakes that varied from blue (clear) to green water reflecting low to high algal levels.

 

We conducted rapid spatial sampling using a flow through system in which lake water is passed by sensors as the position of a moving boat is recorded as it travelled across the lake surface. This system produced thousands of measurements that were converted to maps. Continuous (i.e., temporal) data were also collected in these lakes using sensors attached to anchored platforms.

 

To compare early warnings of algal blooms based on temporal versus spatial statistics, an experimental lake was fertilized with nitrogen and phosphorus. Based on two measures of algal biomass, early warnings were detected more than 25 days prior to a bloom. Spatial data, however, did not provide early warnings because heterogeneity was low in the small experimental lake. Wind, along with daily heating and cooling, mixed the lake rapidly, which eliminated spatial patterns that occur in larger lakes. Hence, our experiment demonstrated that spatial data were not useful alarms for blooms in such small systems.

 

Lake Mendota in Madison, Wisconsin is a large lake that has frequent algal blooms. Precipitation extremes are increasing in the Midwestern U.S., and storms flush large quantities of nutrients into the lake contributing to blooms. We investigated spatial and temporal variability in algal biomass in Lake Mendota following large (>1-2 inches) summer rain events. Unexpectedly, these storms alternatively resulted in increases, decreases, or no changes in algal pigments; that is, they did not consistently cause blooms and sometimes caused declines. There was detectable spatial variability in phytoplankton though, and high-frequency measurements at a centrally located station missed the full range of algal variability present in spatial measurements. For larger productive lakes such as Lake Mendota, blooms have complex patterns in space and time and the responses to storms are related to prior conditions in the lake. Based on our results, we suggest that combined temporal and spatial monitoring are optimal for supporting real-time management of lakes like Mendota where decisions must be made about drinking water withdrawal and recreation use in the face of algal blooms.

 

Regarding the hypothesis that spatial variability would first increase and then decline across a gradient of lake productivity, we found that spatial variability is indeed lower in oligotrophic lakes, but patterns in mesotrophic and eutrophic lakes are more complex. Spatial heterogeneity is not consistently related to lake productivity and can shift both within a day and within seasons. Practically, this means sampling should include multiple locations with a higher number of sites needed in mesotrophic and eutrophic lakes.

 

Overall, our results indicate both spatial and temporal variability are useful in the context of assessing lake water quality and as potential early warnings for algal blooms. Given ongoing advances in remote sensing, further development of spatial early warning approaches, especially for large lakes is warranted. Spatial measurements should be increasingly useful in assessing lakes near and far from thresholds of change like harmful algal blooms as knowledge and experience with these types of data increases.
